comments:
Iam having problem with the cvs plugin. The login works fine, but there are 
some problems when I expand HEAD.(It works fine with wincvs)

Here are the details.

Client: Concurrent Versions System (CVSNT) 2.0.8 (client/server)
Server: Concurrent Versions System (scast-vc) (CVS) 1.11.1p1 (client/server)

Eclipse Message:

The server reported an error while performing the "cvs update" command. 
: cvs server: Invalid reply from auth server (USERNAME) looking for 
(/cvs) 
: cvs [server aborted]: received broken pipe signal 
: cvs server: Invalid reply from auth server (USERNAME) looking for (DONE) 

Below is the bug log:
--------

The problem remains even with the 'fixed' I20030826. Below are the logs. It 
works with WinCVS.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 -10 Sep 08, 2003 11:53:32.820

for full support.

On the CVS preferneces page, disable the option for auto-detecting the server 
version. This should fix the problem.

On the Team>CVS preference page, please enable the dumping of the protocol 
communications to the console and attach the console output. The output will 
not go to the Eclipse console but instead to the console used to launch 
Eclipse. You may need to restart Eclipse using the following arguments:

-vm /path/to/vm/java.exe -consolelog -debug

The use of java instead of javaw is important.

The trace looks OK. I don't know why the server is rejecting it. From previous 
logs, it appears that the server is running a tailored version of CVS (notice 
the "scast-vc" text in the version string). They may have disabled root 
update. 

The fix for bug 37869 would also help here.
This is the same symptomps that I am seeing at home. Described in Bug 43187
This actually isn't the same as bug 43187.

We would like to figure is all of CVS is broken, or just the repo exploring
code.  We can't do this ourselves, could you do the following and let us know if
it works, thanks!

1. check-out the project from a CVS command line client into your workspace
directory.
2. create a project in Eclipse with the same name as the checked out CVS folder.
This will bring in the contents of the newly checked out CVS folder into Eclipse.
3. From the context menu on the project, select Team > Share Project. Then,
select CVS, click next and then OK. 
4. The project should now be configured with CVS. Now can you perform CVS
operations on the project (e.g. Team > Update, Compare With > Latest from HEAD).

It is a problem with repo exploring code. There was no problem while executing 
the steps. Iam also scaling down the severity.

It looks like this error was due to a customized server. The following link 
outlines the Eclipse CVS funtionality that is supported in such a situation.

http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-vcm-
home/docs/online/cvs_features2.0/cvs-faq.html#server_1a
